title: MPs accuse Northern Powerhouse Minister of imposing an elected mayor on the North East
text:
Two North East MPs have accused the Government of imposing an elected mayor on the North East as part of devolution plans.
It comes after the decision that local authorities will need a directly elected mayor if they are to receive major devolved powers, following the Government's move to overturn a proposal by peers to remove the requirement.
Kevan Jones (L) Labour MP for North Durham and Ian Mearns (R) Labour MP for Gateshead challenged James Wharton in the Commons today. MPs voted to axe the peers' change to the Cities and Local Government Bill by 301 votes to 220, with a majority of 81.
It means the Tory flagship devolution Bill no longer contains the protection introduced in the House of Lords, which was designed to prevent ministers from making it a condition that large powers are only devolved to a city or group of authorities led by a directly elected mayor.
Millions of pounds in funding will be available if an agreement can be reached.
But Northern Powerhouse Minister, James Wharton refuted Kevan Jones and Ian Mearns' claims, insisting the Government was not "imposing" mayors on regions.
James Wharton defended the Government's position in Parliament today. He added that any such move would come first as a proposal from the relevant local authority in return for major powers.
Speaking in the Commons today Mr Wharton said, "Mayors are not being imposed anywhere. If any area has a mayor, it will be because that area, through its democratically elected representatives, has chosen to have one."
MPs are continuing to debate the Bill on the first day of committee stage in the Commons.
